channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Mart√≠nez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: Court rules Trump can't use Alien Enemies Act to deport Venezuelan gang members
item.description: The 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled Tuesday that the Trump administration cannot deport Venezuelan gang members under the Alien Enemies Act.

item.title: Epstein accusers expected to hold rally and speak on Capitol Hill Wednesday
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Lisa Phillips, who says she was sex trafficked by Jeffrey Epstein, about political moves to release more information and about seeking justice for his victims.

item.title: Efforts pick up in Congress to force vote on release of Jeffrey Epstein files
item.description: There's a renewed bipartisan push in Congress for information about the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein to be released, with some members trying to force a vote to release all related files.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: Efforts pick up in Congress to force vote on release of Jeffrey Epstein files, Trump family's cryptocurrency started trading Monday, China displays military might with elaborate parade.

item.title: Author Arundhati Roy discusses her new memoir 'Mother Mary Comes to Me'
item.description: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with acclaimed author Arundhati Roy about her new book "Mother Mary Comes to Me," her first major work of autobiography.

item.title: Judge lets Google keep Chrome but orders other penalties in major antitrust ruling
item.description: In a major antitrust ruling, a federal judge stopped short of ordering Google to sell off its popular Chrome browser, but ordered other penalties against the tech giant.

item.title: Pentagon authorizes up to 600 military lawyers to serve as immigration court judges
item.description: In a rare move, the Pentagon is calling on up to 600 military lawyers to serve as temporary judges in immigration courts as the Trump administration looks to speed up deportations.

item.title: Trump says U.S. Navy struck an alleged Venezuelan boat carrying drug shipment
item.description: Days after sending U.S. gunboats to South American waters, President Trump said the U.S. Navy struck a vessel in the southern Caribbean carrying what he described as a Venezuelan drug shipment.

item.title: Food giant Kraft Heinz to split into two companies
item.description: Food giant Kraft Heinz is splitting up into two companies a decade after the merger that was arranged by billionaire investor Warren Buffett.

item.title: Federal judge rules Trump's use of National Guard in L.A. was illegal
item.description: A federal judge ruled Tuesday that the Trump administration's use of the National Guard in Los Angeles was illegal. Meanwhile, the president maintained his intention to send troops to Chicago.
